subject: Re: Looking for a JUnit diff and trend analysis tool
msgSnippet: ... files and ... look at ... optimized ... parsed ... interesting ... Is there such a tool for eclipse/perforce?
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, jason r tibbetts <tibbettj@v...> wrote:
>
> sachin.dholakia@t... wrote:
> > Hi Klaus,
> >
> > There is a tool namely QALAB which is used to pick info from XML
files and
> > generate so called Movers and Shakers of build. You want to have a
look at
> > it.
>
> Thanks for that tip! That looks even better than the Maven Historical
> plugin that I recommended in another response.
>
> >
> > David Saff <saff@m...>
> > Sent by: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > 01/05/2006 07:04 PM
> > Please respond to
> > junit@yahoogroups.com
> >
> >
> > To
> > junit@yahoogroups.com
> > cc
> >
> > Subject
> > Re: [junit] Looking for a JUnit diff and trend analysis tool
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Klaus,
> >
> > I wrote a hack for something like this a while ago, but it was
optimized
> > for looking at failing tests over hundreds of program versions,
parsed
> > from text output files. I imagine that you could probably write
> > something to do this yourself as quickly as extracting the
interesting
> > parts from my code.
> >
> > Can you give a few details about what you would be looking for in a
> > trend analysis? Thanks,
> >
> > David Saff
> >
> > kp.berg wrote:
> >
> >
> >>Hi all,
> >>
> >>I know, JUnit 'unit' tests should always pass ;-) But we are using the
> >>JUnit framework to write integration and systemtests as well. So from
> >>time to time, in this area something may go wrong. Therefore I'm
> >>looking for a tool, that generates a report showing only the
> >>differences between current and last JUnit report - which failing
> >>tests were fixed, which tests stopped to pass, which tests were added
> >>and which removed. Additionaly a test trend analysis should be
> >>possible.
> >>
> >>I know, parsing the XML junitreport output and generating the info,
> >>e.g., with the help of a database, would be possible. But is anyone
> >>aware of an existing tool or open source project that can help in this
> >>direction?
>


Is there such a tool for eclipse/perforce?
